pages.title: Meat & Cooking
pages.text: Living off of roots and berries is all well and good, but hardly satisfying. If I want some real food, I've gotta get my hands dirty.$(br2)But, first things first. If I want to sink my teeth into some elite meats, I should understand food safety beforehand.

pages.title: Cooking
pages.text: Most food is better and safer cooked than raw. Below are various ways I could go about cooking:
pages.a_t: Campfires can cook food and provide buffs when resting by their side.
pages.b_t: A rock furnace is a solid option for cooking and smelting ores. Not too healthy...
pages.c_t: A specialized furnace; faster, but can only cook food. Tasty and no traces of tin in your meat.
pages.d_t: A prettier counterpart to the rock furnace made of mud bricks.
pages.e_t: A 25% more efficient clay brick furnace. Better all-around.
pages.f_t: A 75% more efficient masonry brick furnace. One of the most practical options.
pages.g_t: Only requires a lit fire under it and can cook in bulk.
pages.text2: Not everything edible I can find needs cooking, but for the things that do, a campfire or rock furnace will be the most convenient choices.

pages.title: Meat
pages.text: There seems to be some animals around. I wouldn't mind some protein to get me through the day!
pages.text2: Eating raw meat isn't very pleasant, and might even be hazardous in some cases. I should always cook my meats before eating; it's safer and more filling, anyways.

pages.text: These aren't the only meats I can find, of course; nearly every animal I might come across has something yummy on its bones, from the smallest frogs to the most hulking bulls. $(br2)That being said, I shouldn't expect all of them to go down without a fight.$(br2)Killing animals also yields many useful byproducts like $(thing)tallow$(), $(thing)leather$(), $(thing)wool$() and $(thing)feathers$(), which all may come in handy later.

pages.title: Seafood
pages.text: There's plenty of water around here; if I'm feeling pescatarian, I could always go for something more aquatic:
pages.d_t: Eels from rivers. Like to bite.
pages.e_t: Crab from beaches. Don't get too close!
pages.f_t: Piranhas from ponds and lakes. Very feisty.
pages.text2: Aside from jumping into the water myself and getting all wet, I can also kick back and go fishing by making a crude fishing rod like so:

pages.text: After the fish bites the hook, I should reel in fast before it can escape.$(br2)I shouldn't expect something so hastily cobbled together to last; it may unexpectedly break after reeling something in.
